origins: Zoroastrianism (ancient Persian religion, c. 1500-600 BCE); represents the divine Fravashi (guardian spirit)
prohibitions: Respect the sacred Zoroastrian religious tradition
Not to be used mockingly or disrespectfully
Should maintain understanding of its spiritual function
Avoid trivializing the guardian spirit concept

christianComparativeNotes.overview: Zoroastrianism has a unique relationship with Christianity. The Magi who visited the infant Jesus were likely Zoroastrian priests. Zoroastrian concepts of cosmic dualism, angels, resurrection, and final judgment may have influenced Second Temple Judaism and early Christianity. The Faravahar as a symbol of the soul's journey toward God and the battle between good and evil resonates with Christian themes.

magi.text: Now after Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judea in the days of Herod the king, behold, wise men (magoi) from the east came to Jerusalem
magi.significance: The Magi were likely Zoroastrian priests from Persia. Their recognition of Jesus' birth suggests a providential connection between Zoroastrian expectation and Christian fulfillment.
magi.patristic: Church Fathers saw the Magi's visit as demonstrating that even pagan wisdom, at its best, recognized Christ.

persianJewishContact.description: After Cyrus the Great liberated the Jews from Babylon (2 Chronicles 36:22-23; Ezra 1:1-4), Jews lived under Persian rule for two centuries. Jewish-Zoroastrian interaction during this period may have influenced Jewish and later Christian ideas about angels, demons, resurrection, and final judgment.

influence Debates.scholarly: Scholars debate the extent to which Zoroastrian concepts influenced Jewish and Christian theology. Some see significant influence; others argue for independent development or common ancient Near Eastern heritage.

cosmicDualism.zoroastrian: Zoroastrianism posits a cosmic battle between Ahura Mazda (Wise Lord/Good) and Angra Mainyu (Destructive Spirit/Evil)
cosmicDualism.christian: Christianity similarly teaches warfare between God and Satan, good and evil: 'For we do not wrestle against flesh and blood, but against... spiritual forces of evil' (Ephesians 6:12)
cosmicDualism.difference: Christianity maintains absolute monotheism - Satan is a fallen creature, not an eternal counter-principle to God. God is sovereign over evil, which will ultimately be defeated.

angelology.zoroastrian: The Amesha Spentas (Holy Immortals) are divine beings serving Ahura Mazda, each governing an aspect of creation
angelology.christian: Christian angelology includes archangels (Michael, Gabriel, Raphael) and orders of angels. The Amesha Spentas may have influenced Jewish and Christian understanding of angels.
angelology.guardianAngels: The Fravashi (guardian spirit) concept resembles the Christian doctrine of guardian angels: 'See that you do not despise one of these little ones. For I tell you that in heaven their angels always see the face of my Father' (Matthew 18:10)

resurrectionAndJudgment.zoroastrian: Zoroastrianism teaches bodily resurrection (frashkart) and final judgment, with the righteous entering paradise
resurrectionAndJudgment.christian: Christianity's resurrection hope (1 Corinthians 15) and final judgment (Matthew 25:31-46) share these structural elements
resurrectionAndJudgment.note: Whether this represents influence, common origin, or providential preparation is debated.

choiceBetweenGoodAndEvil.faravahar: The Faravahar symbolizes human choice between asha (truth/righteousness) and druj (lie/wickedness)
choiceBetweenGoodAndEvil.christian: Christianity similarly emphasizes moral choice: 'I have set before you life and death, blessing and curse. Therefore choose life' (Deuteronomy 30:19); 'No one can serve two masters' (Matthew 6:24)

wings.faravahar: The wings represent the soul's ascent toward good thoughts, good words, good deeds
wings.christian: Wing imagery in Christianity represents angels, divine protection, and spiritual aspiration: 'He will cover you with his pinions, and under his wings you will find refuge' (Psalm 91:4)

circle.faravahar: The central ring represents the eternal nature of the soul and cosmic order
circle.christian: Christian use of circles (halos, wedding rings) similarly represents eternity and divine perfection

humanFigure.faravahar: The human figure represents the individual's responsibility for moral choice
humanFigure.christian: Christianity affirms human moral agency and accountability before God: 'For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ' (2 Corinthians 5:10)

syriacChristianity.description: Syriac Christians in the Persian Empire had extensive contact with Zoroastrians. This produced both conflict and dialogue, with Christian writers engaging Zoroastrian concepts.
syriacChristianity.martyrdom: Many Syriac Christians suffered martyrdom under Zoroastrian Sasanian rulers, particularly during periods when Christianity was seen as aligned with the Roman enemy.

modernDialogue.description: Contemporary interreligious dialogue between Christians and Zoroastrians explores shared ethical commitments, monotheistic (or at least henotheistic) theology, and concern for eschatological hope.
sharedValues: Hope for resurrection and final judgment
Role of divine beings in cosmic order
differences: Christianity's Trinitarian monotheism vs. Zoroastrian understanding of divinity
The nature and origin of evil

cyrusAsMessiah.text: Thus says the LORD to his anointed (mashiach/messiah), to Cyrus, whose right hand I have grasped, to subdue nations before him
cyrusAsMessiah.significance: The Hebrew Bible uniquely calls the Persian king Cyrus 'messiah' (anointed one) because he liberated the Jews and allowed the Temple's rebuilding. This remarkable title for a non-Jew suggests divine purpose working through Persian history.

notAdoptable.explanation: Unlike the Ankh (adopted by Coptic Christianity) or the Triquetra (adopted for Trinitarian symbolism), the Faravahar is too specifically Zoroastrian to be adopted as a Christian symbol. However, Christians can appreciate it as part of a religious tradition that intersected with biblical history and may have contributed to the religious vocabulary in which Christianity emerged.
notAdoptable.respect: Christian engagement with the Faravahar should be respectful, recognizing Zoroastrianism as a living faith tradition and honoring the Zoroastrian community's ownership of their symbols.
